citation.title: U.S. Census Popular Modes of Transportation in Boston
citation.shortDescription: Estimated modes of transportation as a percent of total workers over the age of 16, aggregated to the census tract level; geography covers the City of Boston; time period covers 2014-2018 as a five year average
citation.fullDescription: This dataset represents modes of transportation as a percent of total workers over the age of 16. The data originates from the United States Census Bureau's American Community Survey. The Census Bureau has aggregated individual survey responses to census tract geographies. The LMEC worked with cartographer Daniel Huffman to process the census data. We created a new dataset from the census data to study popular modes of transportation in Boston. The geography covers the City of Boston. The time coverage compares changes between 2006-2010 and 2014-2018, each as five-year averages.
citation.accessCondition: This dataset is in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use.

endpoints.title: Boston Modes of Transportation Statistical Tables

temporal.temporalNotes: This dataset is derived as rolling estimates from the 2014-2018 5-year American Community Survey

ingredients.notes: This census tract geography data was joined to census statistical demographic data
This statistical census demographic data was joined to census tract geography data

processing.steps:
1. We downloaded statistics about modes of transportation from a census data download tool 
 2. We also downloaded census tract GIS boundary files from the same tool 
 3. We edited the data tables to only include important information about the topic of study 
 4. We renamed columns with human-readable column headers 
 5. We documented the new names in a codebook 
 6. We combined the new data tables to the GIS boundary files using GIS software to create the final dataset

representation.healthCheckQualifier:
Official census documentation details how survey questions were first developed. It describes how ACS project designers first included stakeholders in that process. 
 
 When it comes to future data collection and survey design, there is less information. The documentation does not address plans to include those the the data is most likely to affect.

publicResponsibility.healthCheckQualifier:
Census documentation is clear about methods used for anonymizing and participant privacy. It discusses the challenges of grouping or [aggregating](http://wiki.gis.com/wiki/index.php/Aggregation) survey responses into homogenous areas. It acknowledges Census Bureau reasoning for why the survey is mandatory. It explains why the data is beneficial to society. 
 
 The documentation does not address how the Census Bureau understands participant consent. It is not clear if all participants understand how their data will be used.

historicContext.healthCheckQualifier: The documentation does not reflect on the ways the data program is at risk for repeating past harms. It does not describe the ways in which U.S. census data collection has considered its relationship and contribution to systemic injustice.

methodology.healthCheckQualifier:
Official census documentation describes all technical methods used to produce the survey data. Census annual budgets are public and discoverable. 
 
 There are not easy-to-find public materials explaining the budgeting process for everyday citizens.

potentialImpact.healthCheckQualifier:
Documentation is clear about potential positive impact from the data. Public materials also outline future funding dependent on this data program. 
 
 There is not discoverable information about potential negative impact. The documentation could be more clear how someone should and should not use the data. There are not accessible guides about known limitations for any given set of census data.

publishedWorks.title: Most popular mode of commuting : 2014-2018 American Community Survey
publishedWorks.author: Huffman, Daniel P.
publishedWorks.publisher: Boston Public Library. Norman B. Leventhal Map and Education Center

codebooks.title: Renamed Fields Dictionary
codebooks.notes: Cartographer Daniel Huffman provided a codebook for how they renamed fields when cleaning this dataset.
